3.5.7 Patterns in Variance Components
Several patterns emerge from Table¬†3.1:
1. Production and carcass traits generally have moderate to high heritability - Growth rate, body weight, carcass composition, egg weight: \(h^2 = 0.30\) to \(0.60\) - These traits respond well to selection - Phenotype is a reasonably good indicator of genetic merit
2. Reproductive and fitness traits have low heritability - Litter size, fertility, survival, disease resistance: \(h^2 = 0.05\) to \(0.15\) - These traits are challenging to improve through selection - Require extensive data and sophisticated breeding value estimation - Genomic selection (Chapter 13) has been particularly valuable for these traits
3. Milk and egg production are intermediate - Milk yield, egg production: \(h^2 = 0.25\) to \(0.35\) - Substantial genetic variation, but also substantial environmental influence - Selection is moderately effective
4. Feed efficiency traits are moderately heritable - Feed conversion, residual feed intake: \(h^2 = 0.25\) to \(0.40\) - Historically difficult to improve due to expensive phenotyping - Precision livestock farming (Chapter 23) now enables automated feed intake recording

3.5.8 Variance is Population-Specific
A crucial caveat: variance components and heritability are properties of populations, not traits. The same trait measured in two different populations can have different \(\sigma^2_A\), \(\sigma^2_E\), and \(h^2\) values.
Factors affecting variance components:
Additive genetic variance (\(\sigma^2_A\)) depends on: - Allele frequencies: \(\sigma^2_A\) is maximized when allele frequencies are near 0.50 (high diversity) - Selection history: Long-term selection reduces \(\sigma^2_A\) as favorable alleles approach fixation - Population size: Small, inbred populations have less \(\sigma^2_A\) than large, diverse populations - Mutation and migration: Introduce new variation
Environmental variance (\(\sigma^2_E\)) depends on: - Uniformity of management: Intensive systems (e.g., commercial poultry) have low \(\sigma^2_E\); extensive systems (e.g., range beef) have high \(\sigma^2_E\) - Measurement precision: Automated systems reduce measurement error, lowering \(\sigma^2_E\) - Data quality: Accurate contemporary grouping and fixed effect modeling reduce residual \(\sigma^2_E\)






WarningCommon Misconception: Heritability Is Not ‚ÄúGenetic vs.¬†Environmental Determination‚Äù



Students often misinterpret heritability as describing the relative importance of genes vs.¬†environment for individual trait expression. This is incorrect.
Wrong interpretation: ‚ÄúBackfat has \(h^2 = 0.60\), so 60% of a pig‚Äôs backfat is determined by genetics and 40% by environment.‚Äù
Correct interpretation: ‚Äú60% of the variation in backfat among pigs in this population is due to differences in breeding values, and 40% is due to environmental differences.‚Äù
The distinction matters: - All pigs need both genes and environment to develop backfat - Heritability describes why pigs differ, not how individuals develop - Heritability can change if the population or environment changes (e.g., more uniform management reduces \(\sigma^2_E\), increasing \(h^2\) even though genetics haven‚Äôt changed)
Example: Human height has \(h^2 \approx 0.80\) in developed countries with good nutrition. This doesn‚Äôt mean ‚Äú80% of your height is genetic‚Äù‚Äîit means that in these populations with relatively uniform nutrition, most of the variation between people is due to genetic differences. In a population with severe malnutrition variability, \(h^2\) could be much lower because environmental differences would dominate.



3.5.9 Visualizing Variance Components
To help visualize the partition of phenotypic variance, imagine phenotypic variation as a ‚Äúpie‚Äù that can be sliced into genetic and environmental portions:
High heritability trait (backfat, \(h^2 = 0.60\)): - Large genetic slice (60%) - Smaller environmental slice (40%) - Selection is effective‚Äîmost phenotypic differences reflect genetic differences
Low heritability trait (litter size, \(h^2 = 0.12\)): - Small genetic slice (12%) - Large environmental slice (88%) - Selection is challenging‚Äîphenotypic differences mostly reflect environmental luck
We‚Äôll create visualizations of these concepts in the R Demonstration section (Section 3.8).

3.5.10 Summary of Variance Partitioning
The key insights from this section:

Phenotypic variance can be partitioned into additive genetic, dominance, epistatic, and environmental components
For practical breeding, we often use the simplified model: \(\sigma^2_P = \sigma^2_A + \sigma^2_E\)
High \(\sigma^2_A\) relative to \(\sigma^2_P\) ‚Üí high heritability ‚Üí effective selection
Low \(\sigma^2_A\) relative to \(\sigma^2_P\) ‚Üí low heritability ‚Üí slow genetic progress
Variance components are population-specific, not universal properties of traits
Different traits have vastly different variance component structures, requiring different breeding strategies

In the next section, we‚Äôll work through detailed examples showing how the genetic model applies to specific traits in multiple livestock species.

title: 3¬† The Basic Genetic Model
text:
3.6 Examples Across Species
To solidify your understanding of the basic genetic model, let‚Äôs work through detailed examples from different livestock species. These examples show how the model \(y = \mu + A + E\) applies to real breeding scenarios and how variance components inform breeding decisions.

3.6.1 Example 1: Milk Yield in Holstein Dairy Cattle
Trait: 305-day mature-equivalent milk yield (kg) Population: US Holstein dairy cattle
Population parameters: - Mean (\(\mu\)): 10,500 kg - Phenotypic SD (\(\sigma_P\)): 1,500 kg - Phenotypic variance (\(\sigma^2_P\)): 2,250,000 kg¬≤ - Additive genetic variance (\(\sigma^2_A\)): 675,000 kg¬≤ - Environmental variance (\(\sigma^2_E\)): 1,575,000 kg¬≤ - Heritability (\(h^2\)): 0.30
Three cows from the same herd:
Cow #4217 (High producer) - Phenotype: \(y = 13,200\) kg - True breeding value (unknown to breeder): \(A = +2,100\) kg - Environmental deviation: \(E = +600\) kg - Check: \(y = 10,500 + 2,100 + 600 = 13,200\) kg ‚úì
This cow is a genuinely superior genetic animal (\(A = +2,100\) kg), and she also experienced favorable conditions (+600 kg), perhaps due to excellent feed quality and staying healthy throughout lactation.
Cow #5831 (Moderate producer) - Phenotype: \(y = 11,400\) kg - True breeding value: \(A = +1,800\) kg (actually better genetics than Cow #4217 phenotypically suggests!) - Environmental deviation: \(E = -900\) kg (unfavorable conditions) - Check: \(y = 10,500 + 1,800 - 900 = 11,400\) kg ‚úì
This cow has excellent genetics (\(A = +1,800\) kg), but experienced challenges (‚àí900 kg)‚Äîperhaps mastitis, lameness, or feed delivery issues. Her phenotype underestimates her genetic merit.
Cow #3694 (Below-average producer) - Phenotype: \(y = 9,300\) kg - True breeding value: \(A = -600\) kg (genetically inferior) - Environmental deviation: \(E = -600\) kg - Check: \(y = 10,500 - 600 - 600 = 9,300\) kg ‚úì
This cow is both genetically below average and had poor environmental conditions.
Breeding decisions:
With \(h^2 = 0.30\) (moderate heritability), phenotype is a moderate indicator of genetic merit. If we only had single lactation records:

Cow #4217 would be selected (highest phenotype)
Cow #5831 might be culled or given lower priority (moderate phenotype)
Cow #3694 would be culled (low phenotype)

But with BLUP breeding values (estimated using multiple lactation records, daughters‚Äô production, and genomic information), we can more accurately rank their genetic merit:


Best genetic merit: Cow #4217 (\(A = +2,100\) kg)

Second best: Cow #5831 (\(A = +1,800\) kg) ‚Üê Would be missed with phenotypic selection alone!

Poor genetic merit: Cow #3694 (\(A = -600\) kg)

Implications for daughter performance:
If we use these cows as dams (mated to a bull with breeding value \(A_{sire} = +1,500\) kg):
Daughters from Cow #4217: Expected BV = \((2,100 + 1,500) / 2 = +1,800\) kg Daughters from Cow #5831: Expected BV = \((1,800 + 1,500) / 2 = +1,650\) kg Daughters from Cow #3694: Expected BV = \((-600 + 1,500) / 2 = +450\) kg
Cow #5831‚Äôs daughters will be excellent (+1,650 kg), despite her moderate phenotype in first lactation. This illustrates why accurate breeding value estimation is crucial‚Äîit helps us identify genetically superior animals even when their phenotypes are compromised by environment.

3.6.2 Example 2: Weaning Weight in Angus Beef Cattle
Trait: 205-day adjusted weaning weight (kg) Population: Commercial Angus herd
Population parameters: - Mean (\(\mu\)): 240 kg - Phenotypic variance (\(\sigma^2_P\)): 625 kg¬≤ - Additive genetic variance (\(\sigma^2_A\)): 281 kg¬≤ - Environmental variance (\(\sigma^2_E\)): 344 kg¬≤ - Heritability (\(h^2\)): 0.45
Three bull calves:
Calf #127 (Heavy calf) - Phenotype: \(y = 270\) kg (+30 kg above mean) - Breeding value: \(A = +18\) kg - Environmental effect: \(E = +12\) kg - Check: \(y = 240 + 18 + 12 = 270\) kg ‚úì
This calf is both genetically superior and benefited from favorable conditions (good dam milk production, avoided illness, favorable birth date).
Calf #243 (Average calf) - Phenotype: \(y = 242\) kg (+2 kg above mean) - Breeding value: \(A = +12\) kg (actually above average genetically!) - Environmental effect: \(E = -10\) kg - Check: \(y = 240 + 12 - 10 = 242\) kg ‚úì
This calf has decent genetics but experienced unfavorable conditions‚Äîperhaps born to a first-calf heifer with low milk production, or born late in the season.
Calf #189 (Light calf) - Phenotype: \(y = 220\) kg (‚àí20 kg below mean) - Breeding value: \(A = -8\) kg - Environmental effect: \(E = -12\) kg - Check: \(y = 240 - 8 - 12 = 220\) kg ‚úì
This calf is genetically below average and experienced poor conditions.
Breeding decisions:
With \(h^2 = 0.45\) (moderate-to-high heritability), weaning weight is a fairly reliable indicator of genetic merit. However, environmental effects still matter:
Estimated breeding values (EPDs, Estimated Progeny Differences in beef cattle terminology):
Using the formula \(\hat{A} \approx h^2(y - \mu)\):

Calf #127: \(\hat{A} \approx 0.45 \times 30 = +13.5\) kg (true \(A = +18\) kg‚Äîunderestimated slightly)
Calf #243: \(\hat{A} \approx 0.45 \times 2 = +0.9\) kg (true \(A = +12\) kg‚Äîseverely underestimated due to poor environment!)
Calf #189: \(\hat{A} \approx 0.45 \times (-20) = -9\) kg (true \(A = -8\) kg‚Äîclose)

The simple regression on phenotype misses Calf #243‚Äôs genetic merit because his phenotype was suppressed by poor environment. In practice, EPDs from breed associations use BLUP methods that account for: - Dam‚Äôs milk production (maternal effects) - Contemporary group (birth year, season, management) - Pedigree information (sire and dam EPDs)
This improves accuracy, especially for calves with environmental disadvantages.
Offspring expectations:
If these bulls are used as sires (mated to average cows, \(A = 0\)):

Calf #127‚Äôs offspring: Expected BV = \(18 / 2 = +9\) kg
Calf #243‚Äôs offspring: Expected BV = \(12 / 2 = +6\) kg
Calf #189‚Äôs offspring: Expected BV = \(-8 / 2 = -4\) kg

Calf #243 will produce decent offspring (+6 kg) despite his modest phenotype.

3.6.3 Example 3: Body Weight at 42 Days in Broiler Chickens
Trait: Body weight at 42 days of age (market weight) Population: Commercial broiler line
Population parameters: - Mean (\(\mu\)): 2,800 g - Phenotypic variance (\(\sigma^2_P\)): 10,000 g¬≤ - Additive genetic variance (\(\sigma^2_A\)): 3,500 g¬≤ - Environmental variance (\(\sigma^2_E\)): 6,500 g¬≤ - Heritability (\(h^2\)): 0.35
Three male broilers from the same family:
Bird #4521 - Phenotype: \(y = 3,050\) g (+250 g) - Breeding value: \(A = +140\) g - Environmental effect: \(E = +110\) g - Check: \(y = 2,800 + 140 + 110 = 3,050\) g ‚úì
Genetically superior and favorably positioned in the pen (good feeder access, avoided early disease).
Bird #4527 - Phenotype: \(y = 2,920\) g (+120 g) - Breeding value: \(A = +160\) g (best genetics of the three!) - Environmental effect: \(E = -40\) g - Check: \(y = 2,800 + 160 - 40 = 2,920\) g ‚úì
Best genetic merit but slightly suppressed phenotype due to minor environmental challenges.
Bird #4539 - Phenotype: \(y = 2,700\) g (‚àí100 g) - Breeding value: \(A = -60\) g - Environmental effect: \(E = -40\) g - Check: \(y = 2,800 - 60 - 40 = 2,700\) g ‚úì
Below-average genetics and environment.
Breeding context:
In modern broiler breeding, family-based selection is used: siblings are evaluated together, and the average family performance helps estimate each bird‚Äôs breeding value more accurately than individual phenotype alone.
If these three birds are full siblings (same sire and dam), the family average phenotype is: \[\bar{y}_{family} = (3,050 + 2,920 + 2,700) / 3 = 2,890 \text{ g}\]
The family average is +90 g above population mean, suggesting the family has positive genetic merit. Even Bird #4539, with below-average individual phenotype, might have a positive estimated breeding value once family information is incorporated.
Selection intensity and generation interval:
Broilers have: - Short generation interval (9‚Äì12 months) - High selection intensity (thousands of birds evaluated, top 3‚Äì5% selected) - High reproductive rate (10‚Äì15 chicks per female per week in pedigree nucleus)
Combined with moderate heritability (\(h^2 = 0.35\)), this allows rapid genetic progress‚Äîbroiler growth rate has increased by about 30% per decade through selection.
Offspring expectations:
If Bird #4527 is selected as a sire (best breeding value, \(A = +160\) g) and mated to an average dam (\(A = 0\)):
Expected offspring BV = \(160 / 2 = +80\) g
Over a 9-month generation interval, if breeders consistently select birds with \(A \approx +150\) g, the population mean increases by roughly \(+75\) g per generation (accounting for selection intensity and accuracy). In 10 years (‚âà10 generations), this compounds to ‚âà750 g improvement‚Äîdramatic progress.

3.6.4 Example 4: Racing Performance in Thoroughbred Horses
Trait: Racing time index (lower = faster, expressed as deviations from par time) Population: North American Thoroughbreds
Population parameters: - Mean (\(\mu\)): 0 seconds (standardized) - Phenotypic variance (\(\sigma^2_P\)): 4.0 sec¬≤ - Additive genetic variance (\(\sigma^2_A\)): 0.6 sec¬≤ - Environmental variance (\(\sigma^2_E\)): 3.4 sec¬≤ - Heritability (\(h^2\)): 0.15 (LOW‚Äîracing performance is highly environmental)
Three horses:
Horse A (Fast racer) - Phenotype: \(y = -1.2\) sec (1.2 seconds faster than par) - Breeding value: \(A = -0.3\) sec (modestly superior genetics) - Environmental effect: \(E = -0.9\) sec (excellent jockey, favorable track, peak fitness) - Check: \(y = 0 - 0.3 - 0.9 = -1.2\) sec ‚úì
This horse is a successful racer, but most of the fast times are due to environment (training, jockey skill, race strategy, track conditions), not genetics.
Horse B (Moderate racer) - Phenotype: \(y = -0.3\) sec (slightly faster than par) - Breeding value: \(A = -0.4\) sec (better genetics than Horse A!) - Environmental effect: \(E = +0.1\) sec (slightly unfavorable conditions) - Check: \(y = 0 - 0.4 + 0.1 = -0.3\) sec ‚úì
This horse has better genetic merit than Horse A but worse race results due to less optimal management or luck.
Horse C (Slow racer) - Phenotype: \(y = +0.8\) sec (slower than par) - Breeding value: \(A = +0.2\) sec (slightly inferior genetics) - Environmental effect: \(E = +0.6\) sec (poor training, injury, unfavorable conditions) - Check: \(y = 0 + 0.2 + 0.6 = +0.8\) sec ‚úì
Below-average genetics and poor environmental conditions.
Breeding implications:
With very low heritability (\(h^2 = 0.15\)), racing performance is a poor predictor of genetic merit. This explains several puzzling observations in Thoroughbred breeding:

Many successful racehorses fail as stallions: Their racing success was largely environmental, not genetic
Some unsuccessful racehorses become excellent sires: They had genetic potential that wasn‚Äôt realized on the track due to injury, poor training, or bad luck
Progeny testing is critical: The best way to evaluate a stallion is to observe his offspring‚Äôs performance (which reveals his true breeding value more accurately than his own race record)

Offspring expectations:
If Horse A is used as a stallion (mated to an average mare, \(A = 0\)):
Expected offspring BV = \(-0.3 / 2 = -0.15\) sec
If Horse B is used as a stallion:
Expected offspring BV = \(-0.4 / 2 = -0.20\) sec (better!)
Horse B will produce slightly faster offspring on average, despite his inferior race record. This is why Thoroughbred breeding is challenging‚Äîthe animals with the best genetic merit aren‚Äôt always the ones with the flashiest racing careers.
In practice, Thoroughbred breeders rely heavily on: - Pedigree: Famous sires and dams command premium stud fees - Progeny testing: A stallion‚Äôs value increases if his offspring consistently run fast - Dosage and nicking theories: Attempting to identify favorable genetic combinations (though these have mixed scientific support)

Key takeaways from these examples:

The basic model \(y = \mu + A + E\) applies universally across species and traits

Environmental effects can be large, even for moderately heritable traits‚Äîthis is why accurate breeding value estimation is crucial
Selection strategies must adapt to the trait‚Äôs heritability and the species‚Äô biology (generation interval, reproductive rate, cost of phenotyping)
Modern methods (BLUP, genomic selection) help us ‚Äúsee through‚Äù environmental noise to identify true genetic merit, especially for lowly heritable traits

These examples reinforce why animal breeding is both a science (quantitative genetics) and an art (interpreting data in context). The next section explores parent-offspring relationships mathematically, showing how breeding values transmit from one generation to the next.

title: 3¬† The Basic Genetic Model
text:
3.7 Parent-Offspring Relationships
One of the most beautiful and fundamental results in quantitative genetics is the linear relationship between parent and offspring breeding values. This relationship is the foundation for predicting response to selection, estimating heritability, and designing breeding programs.

3.7.1 The Fundamental Relationship
When two animals mate, their offspring inherits one allele at each locus from each parent. This leads to a simple but profound relationship:
\[
A_{offspring} = \frac{1}{2}A_{sire} + \frac{1}{2}A_{dam} + MS
\]
Where: - \(A_{offspring}\) = Breeding value of the offspring - \(A_{sire}\) = Breeding value of the sire - \(A_{dam}\) = Breeding value of the dam - \(MS\) = Mendelian sampling deviation (random term)
Let‚Äôs unpack each component:
Midparent breeding value (\(\frac{1}{2}A_{sire} + \frac{1}{2}A_{dam}\)):
The offspring‚Äôs expected breeding value is the average of its parents‚Äô breeding values. This makes intuitive sense: if you mate two animals with breeding values of +10 and +20, the offspring‚Äôs expected breeding value is (+10 + 20) / 2 = +15.
This is true on average across many offspring, but any individual offspring will deviate from this expectation due to Mendelian sampling.
Mendelian sampling (\(MS\)):
At each locus, the offspring randomly receives one of the sire‚Äôs two alleles and one of the dam‚Äôs two alleles. This random sampling creates variation among offspring from the same parents‚Äîfull siblings have the same expected breeding value (midparent average) but different realized breeding values.
Properties of Mendelian sampling: - Mean: \(E(MS) = 0\) (on average, no deviation from midparent) - Variance: \(\text{Var}(MS) = \frac{1}{2}\sigma^2_A\) (in randomly mating populations) - Distribution: Approximately normal for polygenic traits

3.7.2 Example: Swine Growth Rate
Consider a mating between a boar and sow for growth rate (average daily gain):
Parents: - Boar: \(A_{sire} = +80\) g/day - Sow: \(A_{dam} = +60\) g/day
Expected offspring breeding value: \[
E(A_{offspring}) = \frac{1}{2}(+80) + \frac{1}{2}(+60) = +70 \text{ g/day}
\]
Actual offspring (with Mendelian sampling):

Across many offspring, the Mendelian sampling deviations average out to zero, and the mean offspring breeding value equals the midparent value (+70 g/day).
Why does Mendelian sampling occur?
Even though both parents are genetically superior (both have positive breeding values), they‚Äôre not homozygous superior at every locus. For example:

At Locus 1: Boar might be \(B_1B_1\) (homozygous beneficial), Sow might be \(B_1b_1\) (heterozygous)
At Locus 2: Boar might be \(B_2b_2\) (heterozygous), Sow might be \(b_2b_2\) (homozygous inferior)
And so on for thousands of loci‚Ä¶

Depending on which alleles the offspring samples from each parent, it might get: - Lucky: More beneficial alleles than expected ‚Üí positive MS - Average: About the expected mix ‚Üí MS ‚âà 0 - Unlucky: More inferior alleles than expected ‚Üí negative MS
This is why full siblings can be quite different genetically‚Äîthey have the same expected breeding value, but different Mendelian sampling realizations.

3.7.3 Offspring Phenotype Expectations
Combining the breeding value relationship with the phenotypic model (\(y = \mu + A + E\)), we can predict offspring phenotypes:
\[
E(y_{offspring}) = \mu + E(A_{offspring}) + E(E_{offspring})
\]
Since \(E(A_{offspring}) = \frac{1}{2}(A_{sire} + A_{dam})\) and \(E(E_{offspring}) = 0\):
\[
E(y_{offspring}) = \mu + \frac{1}{2}(A_{sire} + A_{dam})
\]
The expected phenotype of offspring equals the population mean plus half the sum of the parents‚Äô breeding values.
Example: If the population mean growth rate is 750 g/day, and we mate the boar (\(A = +80\)) and sow (\(A = +60\)) from above:
\[
E(y_{offspring}) = 750 + \frac{1}{2}(80 + 60) = 750 + 70 = 820 \text{ g/day}
\]
Individual offspring will vary around this expectation due to Mendelian sampling and environmental effects:
\[
y_{offspring} = 750 + 70 + MS + E
\]
If \(\sigma^2_A = 2,500\) g¬≤/day¬≤, then \(\text{Var}(MS) = \frac{1}{2}\sigma^2_A = 1,250\) g¬≤/day¬≤, so \(\sigma_{MS} = 35.4\) g/day.
If \(\sigma^2_E = 1,500\) g¬≤/day¬≤, then \(\sigma_E = 38.7\) g/day.
The phenotypic standard deviation for offspring from these parents is:
\[
\sigma_{y,offspring} = \sqrt{\text{Var}(MS) + \sigma^2_E} = \sqrt{1,250 + 1,500} = 52.4 \text{ g/day}
\]
So we‚Äôd expect offspring phenotypes to be roughly 820 ¬± 105 g/day (mean ¬± 2 SD), with most falling between 715 and 925 g/day.

3.7.4 Parent-Offspring Regression and Heritability
The relationship between parent and offspring breeding values provides a way to estimate heritability from data. Consider the regression of offspring phenotype on midparent phenotype:
\[
y_{offspring} = \alpha + \beta \times y_{midparent} + residual
\]
Where \(y_{midparent} = (y_{sire} + y_{dam}) / 2\).
The slope of this regression (\(\beta\)) is related to heritability:
\[
\beta = h^2
\]
Why? Because: 1. Offspring breeding value = \(\frac{1}{2}(A_{sire} + A_{dam})\) (expected, on average) 2. Midparent breeding value = \(\frac{1}{2}(A_{sire} + A_{dam})\) (exactly) 3. The covariance between offspring and midparent phenotypes depends on \(\sigma^2_A\)
The regression slope turns out to equal the heritability. This provides a classical method for estimating \(h^2\) from family data.
Example regression:
Suppose we measure 100 sire-dam pairs and their 500 offspring (5 per pair on average) for weaning weight in swine. We plot offspring weaning weight (y-axis) vs.¬†midparent weaning weight (x-axis) and fit a linear regression:

If the slope is \(\beta = 0.30\), then \(\hat{h}^2 = 0.30\) (30% of phenotypic variance is additive genetic)
If the slope is \(\beta = 0.60\), then \(\hat{h}^2 = 0.60\) (60% additive genetic)

The scatter around the regression line represents: - Mendelian sampling: Even with the same parents (same midparent value), offspring vary - Environmental effects: Offspring experience different environments

3.7.5 Why Offspring Don‚Äôt Equal Their Parents
Students sometimes wonder: ‚ÄúIf offspring inherit half their genes from each parent, why don‚Äôt offspring exactly equal the midparent average?‚Äù
Three reasons:
1. Mendelian sampling (genetic reason):
Even though offspring inherit 50% of alleles from each parent, which alleles they inherit is random. Parents are heterozygous at many loci, so offspring can get better or worse combinations than expected.
2. Environmental effects (non-genetic reason):
Offspring phenotypes include environmental deviations (\(E\)). Even if an offspring‚Äôs breeding value exactly equals the midparent breeding value (no Mendelian sampling deviation), its phenotype will differ due to environment:
\[
y_{offspring} = \mu + \frac{1}{2}(A_{sire} + A_{dam}) + E_{offspring}
\]
The parents‚Äô phenotypes included their environmental effects:
\[
y_{sire} = \mu + A_{sire} + E_{sire}
\] \[
y_{dam} = \mu + A_{dam} + E_{dam}
\]
The offspring doesn‚Äôt inherit \(E_{sire}\) or \(E_{dam}\)‚Äîit gets its own independent \(E_{offspring}\).
3. Dominance and epistasis (non-additive genetic reasons):
If parents had favorable dominance or epistatic deviations, those don‚Äôt transmit reliably. The offspring might have different dominance/epistatic values depending on which specific genotype combinations form.

3.7.6 Regression Toward the Mean
A consequence of the parent-offspring relationship is regression toward the mean: offspring of extreme parents tend to be less extreme than their parents (though still better/worse than average in the same direction).
Why? Because offspring breeding value = 1/2 (midparent breeding value), not the full parental deviation.
Example:

Population mean: 750 g/day
Elite boar with phenotype 900 g/day and breeding value \(A = +100\) g/day (the rest is environmental)
Elite sow with phenotype 880 g/day and breeding value \(A = +80\) g/day

Expected offspring breeding value: \[
E(A_{offspring}) = \frac{1}{2}(100 + 80) = +90 \text{ g/day}
\]
Expected offspring phenotype (with average environment): \[
E(y_{offspring}) = 750 + 90 = 840 \text{ g/day}
\]
The parents averaged (900 + 880) / 2 = 890 g/day phenotypically, but offspring are expected to average only 840 g/day. This is regression toward the mean‚Äîoffspring are still well above average (+90 g/day), but not as extreme as their parents‚Äô phenotypes suggested.
This is not a failure of selection‚Äîthe offspring are genetically superior (+90 g/day breeding value). It‚Äôs simply that: 1. Offspring inherit half of each parent‚Äôs breeding value (dilution effect) 2. Offspring don‚Äôt inherit their parents‚Äô lucky environments

3.7.7 Full-Sib vs.¬†Half-Sib Families
The parent-offspring relationship helps us understand why different types of relatives resemble each other:
Full siblings (same sire and dam): - Expected breeding value: Same for all (midparent average) - Variation: Due to Mendelian sampling (Var = \(\frac{1}{2}\sigma^2_A\)) - Correlation: \(r_{full-sib} = \frac{1}{2}\) (ignoring dominance)
Half siblings (same sire, different dams, or vice versa): - Share one parent, so they share 25% of alleles identical by descent - Correlation: \(r_{half-sib} = \frac{1}{4}\)
These correlations form the basis for estimating heritability from family data (paternal half-sib design is common in livestock).

3.7.8 Summary of Parent-Offspring Relationships
Key insights from this section:

Offspring breeding value equals midparent breeding value, on average: \(E(A_{offspring}) = \frac{1}{2}(A_{sire} + A_{dam})\)
Mendelian sampling creates variation among full siblings‚Äîthey have the same expected BV but different realized BVs
Parent-offspring regression slope equals heritability (\(\beta = h^2\)), providing a way to estimate \(h^2\)
Regression toward the mean occurs because offspring inherit half of parental genetic merit and don‚Äôt inherit environmental effects
Resemblance between relatives (full sibs, half sibs, parent-offspring) depends on the proportion of alleles shared and provides information for estimating genetic parameters

In the next section, we‚Äôll use R to simulate these concepts and visualize parent-offspring relationships under different heritability scenarios.

title: 3¬† The Basic Genetic Model
section: 3.8 R Demonstration: Simulating the Basic Model
text:
3.8 R Demonstration: Simulating the Basic Model
Now let‚Äôs bring these concepts to life using R simulations. We‚Äôll demonstrate:

Simulating phenotypes from the basic model
Visualizing genetic vs.¬†environmental contributions
Parent-offspring regression and heritability estimation
Comparing traits with different heritabilities

These simulations will help you develop intuition for how the genetic model works in practice.

3.8.1 Demonstration 1: Simulating Phenotypes
Let‚Äôs start by simulating a population of 1,000 animals and decomposing their phenotypes into genetic and environmental components.

# Set seed for reproducibility
set.seed(42)

# Population size
n_animals <- 1000

# Population parameters (example: weaning weight in swine, kg)
mu <- 6.0          # Population mean
sigma_A <- 0.8     # Additive genetic SD (breeding value variation)
sigma_E <- 1.2     # Environmental SD

# Calculate variance components
sigma2_A <- sigma_A^2
sigma2_E <- sigma_E^2
sigma2_P <- sigma2_A + sigma2_E
h2 <- sigma2_A / sigma2_P

# Simulate breeding values (additive genetic effects)
A <- rnorm(n_animals, mean = 0, sd = sigma_A)

# Simulate environmental deviations
E <- rnorm(n_animals, mean = 0, sd = sigma_E)

# Calculate phenotypes
y <- mu + A + E

# Create dataframe
population <- data.frame(
  animal_id = 1:n_animals,
  breeding_value = A,
  environment = E,
  phenotype = y
)

# Summary statistics
cat("Population Parameters:\n")

Population Parameters:

cat(sprintf("Mean phenotype: %.2f kg\n", mean(y)))

Mean phenotype: 5.97 kg

cat(sprintf("SD of breeding values: %.2f kg\n", sd(A)))

SD of breeding values: 0.80 kg

cat(sprintf("SD of environmental effects: %.2f kg\n", sd(E)))

SD of environmental effects: 1.18 kg

cat(sprintf("SD of phenotypes: %.2f kg\n", sd(y)))

SD of phenotypes: 1.44 kg

cat(sprintf("\nVariance Components:\n"))


Variance Components:

cat(sprintf("œÉ¬≤_A = %.3f kg¬≤\n", var(A)))

œÉ¬≤_A = 0.643 kg¬≤

cat(sprintf("œÉ¬≤_E = %.3f kg¬≤\n", var(E)))

œÉ¬≤_E = 1.400 kg¬≤

cat(sprintf("œÉ¬≤_P = %.3f kg¬≤\n", var(y)))

œÉ¬≤_P = 2.062 kg¬≤

cat(sprintf("Heritability (h¬≤) = %.2f\n", h2))

Heritability (h¬≤) = 0.31

# Visualize phenotype distribution
ggplot(population, aes(x = phenotype)) +
  geom_histogram(aes(y = after_stat(density)), bins = 40,
                 fill = "steelblue", alpha = 0.7, color = "black") +
  geom_vline(xintercept = mu, color = "red", linewidth = 1, linetype = "dashed") +
  stat_function(fun = dnorm, args = list(mean = mu, sd = sqrt(sigma2_P)),
                color = "darkblue", linewidth = 1.2) +
  annotate("text", x = mu + 0.5, y = 0.25, label = paste("Œº =", mu, "kg"),
           color = "red", size = 4) +
  labs(title = "Phenotype Distribution: y = Œº + A + E",
       subtitle = paste0("n = ", n_animals, ", h¬≤ = ", round(h2, 2)),
       x = "Weaning Weight (kg)",
       y = "Density") +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 12)



Distribution of phenotypes simulated from the basic model y = Œº + A + E. The population shows continuous variation around the mean.



Interpretation:

The histogram shows the distribution of phenotypes across the population
The red dashed line marks the population mean (Œº = 6.0 kg)
The phenotypic distribution is approximately normal, as expected for a polygenic trait
The phenotypic standard deviation (œÉ_P ‚âà 1.44 kg) is larger than either the genetic (œÉ_A = 0.8 kg) or environmental (œÉ_E = 1.2 kg) SD alone‚Äîvariation comes from both sources

3.8.2 Demonstration 2: Visualizing Variance Components
Let‚Äôs visualize how much of each animal‚Äôs phenotypic deviation from the mean is due to genetics vs.¬†environment.

# Select 20 random animals for visualization
set.seed(123)
sample_animals <- population %>%
  slice_sample(n = 20) %>%
  arrange(phenotype) %>%
  mutate(animal_label = paste0("Animal ", row_number()))

# Create stacked bar plot showing A and E contributions
sample_animals_long <- sample_animals %>%
  select(animal_label, breeding_value, environment) %>%
  pivot_longer(cols = c(breeding_value, environment),
               names_to = "component",
               values_to = "value") %>%
  mutate(component = factor(component,
                            levels = c("breeding_value", "environment"),
                            labels = c("Genetic (A)", "Environmental (E)")))

ggplot(sample_animals_long, aes(x = animal_label, y = value, fill = component)) +
  geom_col(position = "stack") +
  geom_hline(yintercept = 0, linewidth = 0.5) +
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("Genetic (A)" = "#2E86AB",
                                "Environmental (E)" = "#A23B72")) +
  labs(title = "Genetic vs. Environmental Contributions to Phenotypic Deviation",
       subtitle = paste0("Deviation from population mean (Œº = ", mu, " kg)"),
       x = "Animal",
       y = "Deviation from Mean (kg)",
       fill = "Component") +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 11) +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1),
        legend.position = "top")



Decomposition of phenotypic deviations into genetic (A) and environmental (E) components for 20 randomly selected animals. Bar colors show the relative contributions.



Interpretation:

Each bar represents an animal‚Äôs total deviation from the population mean
The blue portion (A) is the genetic contribution (breeding value)
The pink portion (E) is the environmental contribution
Some animals are above average due to good genetics (positive A) and/or favorable environment (positive E)
Others are below average due to poor genetics (negative A) and/or unfavorable environment (negative E)
The challenge in animal breeding is that we observe the total bar height (phenotype) but want to know the blue component (breeding value)

3.8.3 Demonstration 3: Comparing High vs.¬†Low Heritability Traits
Let‚Äôs simulate two traits with different heritabilities to see how this affects the genetic vs.¬†environmental contributions.

# High heritability trait (e.g., backfat depth in swine)
h2_high <- 0.60
sigma_P_high <- 3.0  # Phenotypic SD (mm)
sigma_A_high <- sqrt(h2_high * sigma_P_high^2)
sigma_E_high <- sqrt((1 - h2_high) * sigma_P_high^2)

# Low heritability trait (e.g., litter size in swine)
h2_low <- 0.12
sigma_P_low <- 2.5  # Phenotypic SD (piglets)
sigma_A_low <- sqrt(h2_low * sigma_P_low^2)
sigma_E_low <- sqrt((1 - h2_low) * sigma_P_low^2)

# Create data for visualization
variance_data <- data.frame(
  trait = rep(c("High h¬≤ (0.60)\nBackfat depth",
                "Low h¬≤ (0.12)\nLitter size"), each = 2),
  component = rep(c("Genetic (A)", "Environmental (E)"), 2),
  proportion = c(h2_high, 1 - h2_high, h2_low, 1 - h2_low),
  variance = c(sigma_A_high^2, sigma_E_high^2, sigma_A_low^2, sigma_E_low^2)
) %>%
  mutate(label = scales::percent(proportion, accuracy = 1))

# Create stacked bar chart comparison
ggplot(variance_data, aes(x = trait, y = proportion, fill = component)) +
  geom_col(width = 0.6) +
  geom_text(aes(label = label), position = position_stack(vjust = 0.5),
            color = "white", fontface = "bold", size = 5) +
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("Genetic (A)" = "#2E86AB",
                                "Environmental (E)" = "#A23B72")) +
  scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::percent, expand = c(0, 0)) +
  labs(title = "Variance Partitioning: High vs. Low Heritability Traits",
       subtitle = "Proportion of phenotypic variance due to genetics (A) vs. environment (E)",
       x = NULL,
       y = "Proportion of Phenotypic Variance",
       fill = "Component") +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 12) +
  theme(legend.position = "bottom",
        axis.text.x = element_text(size = 11, face = "bold"),
        panel.grid.major.x = element_blank())



Comparison of variance components for high heritability trait (h¬≤ = 0.60, like backfat) vs.¬†low heritability trait (h¬≤ = 0.12, like litter size). Bar charts show the proportion of phenotypic variance due to genetics vs.¬†environment.



Interpretation:
High heritability trait (h¬≤ = 0.60, Backfat): - 60% of variation is genetic ‚Üí phenotypes are good indicators of breeding values - 40% of variation is environmental - Selection is effective ‚Üí choosing animals with low backfat usually means choosing animals with good genetics
Low heritability trait (h¬≤ = 0.12, Litter size): - Only 12% of variation is genetic ‚Üí phenotypes are poor indicators of breeding values - 88% of variation is environmental ‚Üí most differences between sows are due to luck - Selection is challenging ‚Üí need many records and sophisticated methods (BLUP, genomic selection) to accurately estimate breeding values

3.8.4 Demonstration 4: Parent-Offspring Regression
Let‚Äôs simulate parent-offspring pairs and visualize the regression relationship, which provides an estimate of heritability.

# Function to simulate parent-offspring pairs
simulate_families <- function(n_families, h2, mu = 100, sigma_P = 15) {
  sigma_A <- sqrt(h2 * sigma_P^2)
  sigma_E <- sqrt((1 - h2) * sigma_P^2)

  # Simulate parents
  sires <- tibble(
    sire_id = 1:n_families,
    A_sire = rnorm(n_families, 0, sigma_A),
    E_sire = rnorm(n_families, 0, sigma_E),
    y_sire = mu + A_sire + E_sire
  )

  dams <- tibble(
    dam_id = 1:n_families,
    A_dam = rnorm(n_families, 0, sigma_A),
    E_dam = rnorm(n_families, 0, sigma_E),
    y_dam = mu + A_dam + E_dam
  )

  # Simulate offspring (5 per family)
  offspring_per_family <- 5
  offspring <- crossing(sire_id = 1:n_families, offspring_num = 1:offspring_per_family) %>%
    left_join(sires, by = "sire_id") %>%
    left_join(dams %>% rename(sire_id = dam_id), by = "sire_id") %>%
    mutate(
      # Offspring breeding value = midparent + Mendelian sampling
      A_midparent = (A_sire + A_dam) / 2,
      MS = rnorm(n(), 0, sqrt(0.5 * sigma_A^2)),
      A_offspring = A_midparent + MS,
      E_offspring = rnorm(n(), 0, sigma_E),
      y_offspring = mu + A_offspring + E_offspring,
      y_midparent = (y_sire + y_dam) / 2
    )

  return(offspring)
}

# Simulate for high and low heritability
set.seed(456)
n_families <- 100

high_h2_data <- simulate_families(n_families, h2 = 0.60) %>%
  mutate(trait = "High h¬≤ (0.60)")

low_h2_data <- simulate_families(n_families, h2 = 0.15) %>%
  mutate(trait = "Low h¬≤ (0.15)")

combined_data <- bind_rows(high_h2_data, low_h2_data)

# Fit regressions
regression_results <- combined_data %>%
  group_by(trait) %>%
  summarize(
    intercept = coef(lm(y_offspring ~ y_midparent))[1],
    slope = coef(lm(y_offspring ~ y_midparent))[2],
    r_squared = summary(lm(y_offspring ~ y_midparent))$r.squared,
    .groups = "drop"
  )

# Plot parent-offspring regressions
ggplot(combined_data, aes(x = y_midparent, y = y_offspring)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.4, size = 1.5, color = "steelblue") +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = TRUE, color = "darkred", linewidth = 1.2) +
  geom_abline(intercept = 100, slope = 0, linetype = "dashed", color = "gray50") +
  facet_wrap(~ trait) +
  geom_text(data = regression_results,
            aes(x = 85, y = 125,
                label = paste0("Slope (h¬≤) = ", round(slope, 2),
                              "\nR¬≤ = ", round(r_squared, 2))),
            hjust = 0, size = 4, color = "darkred", fontface = "bold") +
  labs(title = "Parent-Offspring Regression: Estimating Heritability",
       subtitle = "Regression slope equals heritability",
       x = "Midparent Phenotype",
       y = "Offspring Phenotype") +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 12) +
  theme(strip.text = element_text(size = 12, face = "bold"))



Parent-offspring regression for two traits with different heritabilities. The regression slope equals the heritability. For high h¬≤, offspring phenotypes closely track parent phenotypes; for low h¬≤, the relationship is weak.



Interpretation:
High heritability (h¬≤ = 0.60): - Steep slope (Œ≤ ‚âà 0.60): Strong parent-offspring resemblance - High R¬≤ (‚âà 0.35‚Äì0.40): Midparent phenotype explains substantial offspring variation - Points cluster tightly around the regression line - Implication: Selecting parents with high phenotypes is effective
Low heritability (h¬≤ = 0.15): - Shallow slope (Œ≤ ‚âà 0.15): Weak parent-offspring resemblance - Low R¬≤ (‚âà 0.05‚Äì0.10): Midparent phenotype explains little offspring variation - Points are widely scattered around the regression line - Implication: Phenotypic selection is ineffective; need better breeding value estimates
The regression slope provides a classical estimate of heritability: \(\hat{h}^2 = \beta\).

3.8.5 Demonstration 5: The Power of BLUP vs.¬†Phenotypic Selection
Let‚Äôs simulate a scenario comparing selection based on phenotype alone vs.¬†selection based on estimated breeding values (simplified BLUP concept).

# Simulate population with moderate heritability
set.seed(789)
n_pop <- 200
h2_mod <- 0.35
mu_mod <- 100
sigma_P_mod <- 15
sigma_A_mod <- sqrt(h2_mod * sigma_P_mod^2)
sigma_E_mod <- sqrt((1 - h2_mod) * sigma_P_mod^2)

population_selection <- tibble(
  animal_id = 1:n_pop,
  A = rnorm(n_pop, 0, sigma_A_mod),
  E = rnorm(n_pop, 0, sigma_E_mod),
  y = mu_mod + A + E
) %>%
  mutate(
    # Simple EBV estimate: regression on phenotype
    EBV = h2_mod * (y - mu_mod),
    rank_phenotype = rank(-y),
    rank_EBV = rank(-EBV),
    rank_true_BV = rank(-A)
  )

# Select top 10% based on phenotype vs. EBV
prop_selected <- 0.10
n_selected <- round(n_pop * prop_selected)

selected_phenotype <- population_selection %>%
  slice_max(y, n = n_selected) %>%
  mutate(selection_method = "Phenotypic Selection")

selected_EBV <- population_selection %>%

Gray points: All animals in the population

Red points: Animals selected based on highest phenotypes

Green points: Animals selected based on highest estimated breeding values (EBVs)

Key insights: 1. Phenotypic selection sometimes picks animals with high phenotypes due to favorable environments (high E), not high breeding values 2. EBV-based selection better identifies animals with truly superior genetics (high A), even if their phenotypes are moderate 3. The improvement from using EBVs instead of phenotypes is typically 5-20% more genetic progress, depending on heritability
This demonstrates why modern breeding programs invest in BLUP and genomic selection‚Äîthey provide more accurate breeding value estimates, leading to faster genetic progress.

3.8.6 Key Takeaways from R Demonstrations

The basic model \(y = \mu + A + E\) can be simulated to create realistic phenotypic distributions
Variance components determine what proportion of phenotypic variation is genetic vs.¬†environmental
Heritability affects selection efficiency: High h¬≤ ‚Üí phenotype is reliable; Low h¬≤ ‚Üí need sophisticated methods
Parent-offspring regression provides a classical method to estimate heritability from data
Breeding value estimation (BLUP, genomic selection) outperforms phenotypic selection by accounting for environmental effects

These simulations provide a foundation for understanding more advanced topics in later chapters, including BLUP (Chapter 7), selection response (Chapter 6), and genomic selection (Chapter 13).

title: 3¬† The Basic Genetic Model
text:
3.9 Summary
This chapter introduced the fundamental genetic model that underlies all of quantitative genetics and animal breeding. Understanding how phenotypes are determined by the combination of genetic and environmental effects is essential for estimating breeding values, predicting response to selection, and designing effective breeding programs.

3.9.1 Key Points
The Basic Genetic Model


Phenotype is the sum of genetic and environmental effects: \(y = \mu + A + E\)


\(y\) = observed phenotype (measurable)

\(\mu\) = population mean (estimable)

\(A\) = additive genetic effect or breeding value (must be estimated)

\(E\) = environmental deviation (unmeasurable for individuals)



The challenge of animal breeding is separating \(A\) from \(E\) so we can identify and select animals with superior genetic merit

Types of Genetic Effects


Genetic effects partition into three types: \(G = A + D + I\)


Additive effects (\(A\)): Sum of average effects of alleles; breed true; determine breeding value

Dominance effects (\(D\)): Within-locus interactions; don‚Äôt breed true; contribute to heterosis in crossbreeding

Epistatic effects (\(I\)): Between-locus interactions; don‚Äôt breed true; largely unpredictable



Only additive effects matter for long-term genetic improvement because:

They transmit predictably from parent to offspring: \(E(A_{offspring}) = \frac{1}{2}(A_{sire} + A_{dam})\)

Response to selection depends on additive genetic variance (\(\sigma^2_A\)), not total genetic variance
Dominance and epistasis ‚Äúwash out‚Äù over generations‚Äîthey don‚Äôt accumulate



Variance Partitioning

Phenotypic variance partitions into components: \(\sigma^2_P = \sigma^2_A + \sigma^2_D + \sigma^2_I + \sigma^2_E\)
In practice, we simplify to: \(\sigma^2_P = \sigma^2_A + \sigma^2_E\)

Heritability (\(h^2 = \sigma^2_A / \sigma^2_P\)) quantifies the proportion of phenotypic variance due to additive genetics

High \(h^2\) (0.40‚Äì0.70): Production and carcass traits ‚Üí effective selection
Low \(h^2\) (0.05‚Äì0.20): Reproductive and fitness traits ‚Üí challenging selection


Variance components are population-specific, not universal properties of traits

Parent-Offspring Relationships

Offspring inherit half of each parent‚Äôs breeding value on average, plus Mendelian sampling variation
Parent-offspring regression slope equals heritability: \(\beta = h^2\)
Regression toward the mean occurs because offspring don‚Äôt inherit environmental effects and inherit only half of parental genetic deviations

Practical Implications

Phenotypic selection is effective for high-h¬≤ traits but misleading for low-h¬≤ traits
Modern breeding methods (BLUP, genomic selection) estimate breeding values more accurately than phenotypic selection alone, especially for lowly heritable traits
Different species and traits require different breeding strategies based on heritability, generation interval, and reproductive rate

This chapter provides the theoretical foundation for the rest of the book. The concepts introduced here‚Äîbreeding values, variance components, heritability‚Äîwill be used throughout Chapters 5‚Äì13 as we develop more sophisticated selection and genomic methods.

title: 3¬† The Basic Genetic Model
text:
3.10 Practice Problems
Work through these problems to test your understanding of the basic genetic model. Solutions are provided below.

3.10.1 Problems

A broiler chicken has a phenotype of 2,950 g for 42-day body weight. The population mean is 2,800 g, and the chicken‚Äôs breeding value is +80 g. What is the environmental deviation for this chicken?
Explain in your own words why dominance effects do not contribute to long-term response to selection, even though they affect individual phenotypes.

For a trait with \(\sigma^2_P = 100\) units¬≤, \(\sigma^2_A = 30\) units¬≤, and \(\sigma^2_E = 60\) units¬≤:

What is \(\sigma^2_D + \sigma^2_I\) (combined dominance and epistatic variance)?
What is the heritability (\(h^2\)) if we use the simplified model \(\sigma^2_P = \sigma^2_A + \sigma^2_E\)?


A boar has a breeding value of +120 g/day for average daily gain. If he is mated to sows with an average breeding value of +60 g/day, what is the expected breeding value of their offspring?
In a dairy cattle population, the heritability of milk yield is 0.35. Two parents have phenotypes of 12,000 kg and 11,400 kg. The population mean is 10,500 kg. Using the simple regression method, estimate the expected breeding value of their offspring. (Hint: Midparent phenotype deviation √ó \(h^2\))
Why do full siblings (same sire and dam) have different phenotypes and different breeding values, even though they have the same expected breeding value?

A trait has phenotypic variance \(\sigma^2_P = 16\) kg¬≤ and heritability \(h^2 = 0.45\). Calculate:

Additive genetic variance (\(\sigma^2_A\))
Environmental variance (\(\sigma^2_E\))
Additive genetic standard deviation (\(\sigma_A\))


Explain why heritability is a population parameter, not a trait parameter. Give an example of how the same trait could have different heritabilities in two populations.

3.10.2 Solutions
Problem 1
Using \(y = \mu + A + E\), we can solve for \(E\):
\[E = y - \mu - A = 2,950 - 2,800 - 80 = +70 \text{ g}\]
The chicken experienced a favorable environmental effect of +70 g (perhaps better feeder access or avoided early disease).

Problem 2
Dominance effects depend on specific genotype combinations at individual loci (having two different alleles creates the dominance effect). When parents reproduce, their alleles segregate and recombine with alleles from the other parent, creating new genotypes in offspring. The specific genotype combination that created the dominance effect in the parent is not preserved in the offspring‚Äîit‚Äôs ‚Äúbroken up‚Äù during meiosis and recombination.
Over generations of selection, we can increase the frequency of beneficial alleles (which changes additive genetic effects), but we cannot reliably select for favorable dominance combinations because they don‚Äôt transmit as stable entities. Therefore, dominance creates short-term variation in individual phenotypes but doesn‚Äôt contribute to long-term, cumulative genetic improvement.

Problem 3

Using the full model: \(\sigma^2_P = \sigma^2_A + \sigma^2_D + \sigma^2_I + \sigma^2_E\)


\[\sigma^2_D + \sigma^2_I = \sigma^2_P - \sigma^2_A - \sigma^2_E = 100 - 30 - 60 = 10 \text{ units}^2\]

Using the simplified model where we lump non-additive effects into environmental variance:

\[h^2 = \frac{\sigma^2_A}{\sigma^2_P} = \frac{30}{100} = 0.30\]
Note: The simplified model treats the 10 units¬≤ of dominance and epistatic variance as part of ‚Äúenvironmental‚Äù (non-heritable) variation.

Problem 4
Offspring breeding value equals the midparent breeding value (on average):
\[E(A_{offspring}) = \frac{1}{2}A_{sire} + \frac{1}{2}A_{dam} = \frac{1}{2}(+120) + \frac{1}{2}(+60) = +90 \text{ g/day}\]
Individual offspring will deviate from +90 g/day due to Mendelian sampling, but across many offspring, the average will be +90 g/day.

Problem 5
Midparent phenotype: \[y_{midparent} = \frac{12,000 + 11,400}{2} = 11,700 \text{ kg}\]
Midparent deviation from population mean: \[y_{midparent} - \mu = 11,700 - 10,500 = +1,200 \text{ kg}\]
Estimated offspring breeding value (using simple regression): \[\hat{A}_{offspring} = h^2 \times (y_{midparent} - \mu) = 0.35 \times 1,200 = +420 \text{ kg}\]
Expected offspring phenotype: \[E(y_{offspring}) = \mu + \hat{A}_{offspring} = 10,500 + 420 = 10,920 \text{ kg}\]
(This assumes average environment for offspring. Individual offspring will vary due to Mendelian sampling and environmental effects.)

Problem 6
Full siblings have different phenotypes and breeding values for two reasons:
1. Mendelian sampling (different breeding values): Even though siblings have the same expected breeding value (midparent average), they sample different alleles from each parent during meiosis. At each locus, a sibling randomly receives one of the parent‚Äôs two alleles. With thousands of loci involved in quantitative traits, different siblings inherit different combinations, creating variation in breeding values. The variance among full-sib breeding values is \(\frac{1}{2}\sigma^2_A\).
2. Environmental effects (different phenotypes): Each sibling experiences unique environmental effects (\(E\)) that affect its phenotype. Even siblings raised in the same pen don‚Äôt have identical environments‚Äîthey compete for feed, experience different health challenges, and undergo random developmental variation. These environmental differences create phenotypic variation even if siblings had identical breeding values.

Problem 7

\(\sigma^2_A = h^2 \times \sigma^2_P = 0.45 \times 16 = 7.2 \text{ kg}^2\)
\(\sigma^2_E = \sigma^2_P - \sigma^2_A = 16 - 7.2 = 8.8 \text{ kg}^2\)
\(\sigma_A = \sqrt{\sigma^2_A} = \sqrt{7.2} = 2.68 \text{ kg}\)

This means breeding values in the population have a standard deviation of 2.68 kg. About 68% of animals have breeding values within ¬±2.68 kg of the population mean.

Problem 8
Heritability is a population parameter because it depends on the amounts of genetic and environmental variation present in a specific population, not on the trait itself.
The same trait can have different heritabilities in different populations because:
Genetic variance (\(\sigma^2_A\)) can differ: - Populations with more genetic diversity (varied allele frequencies) have higher \(\sigma^2_A\) - Populations under long-term selection may have reduced \(\sigma^2_A\) as favorable alleles approach fixation - Small, inbred populations have lower \(\sigma^2_A\) than large, diverse populations
Environmental variance (\(\sigma^2_E\)) can differ: - Populations raised in uniform, controlled environments (e.g., commercial poultry) have low \(\sigma^2_E\) - Populations in variable environments (e.g., range beef cattle) have high \(\sigma^2_E\)
Example:
Consider weaning weight in swine:
Population A (Commercial nucleus herd): - Uniform management, controlled feeding, excellent health care - \(\sigma^2_A = 4.0\) kg¬≤ (maintained diversity) - \(\sigma^2_E = 3.0\) kg¬≤ (low environmental variation) - \(\sigma^2_P = 7.0\) kg¬≤ - \(h^2 = 4.0 / 7.0 = 0.57\)
Population B (Small, backyard herd): - Variable management, mixed feeding, inconsistent health care - \(\sigma^2_A = 2.0\) kg¬≤ (less genetic diversity due to small size) - \(\sigma^2_E = 8.0\) kg¬≤ (high environmental variation) - \(\sigma^2_P = 10.0\) kg¬≤ - \(h^2 = 2.0 / 10.0 = 0.20\)
The same trait (weaning weight) has dramatically different heritabilities (0.57 vs.¬†0.20) in the two populations due to differences in both genetic and environmental variance.

title: 5¬† Heritability and Repeatability
text:
5.1 Introduction
[Content to be developed: Heritability is one of the most important parameters in animal breeding. It tells us how much of the phenotypic variation is due to additive genetics.]

title: 5¬† Heritability and Repeatability
text:
5.2 Heritability (h¬≤)
[Content to be developed: Define heritability.]

5.2.1 Definition
[Content to be developed:]
\[
h^2 = \frac{\sigma^2_A}{\sigma^2_P}
\]
Where:

h¬≤ = narrow-sense heritability
œÉ¬≤_A = additive genetic variance
œÉ¬≤_P = phenotypic variance

5.2.2 Interpretation
[Content to be developed: h¬≤ represents the proportion of phenotypic variation due to additive genetic effects. Range: 0 to 1.]

5.2.3 What Heritability Tells Us
[Content to be developed:]


Resemblance between relatives: Higher h¬≤ means closer resemblance

Response to selection: Higher h¬≤ means faster response

Accuracy of selection: Higher h¬≤ allows more accurate EBV estimation

5.2.4 What Heritability Does NOT Tell Us
[Content to be developed: Common misconceptions]


NOT the proportion ‚Äúcaused‚Äù by genes (all traits are 100% genetic AND 100% environmental)

NOT whether a trait can be changed

NOT importance of genetics vs.¬†environment

NOT fixed - heritability is population- and environment-specific

title: 5¬† Heritability and Repeatability

[Content to be developed: Provide typical heritability ranges for various traits.]

5.4 Estimating Heritability
[Content to be developed: Methods for estimating h¬≤.]

5.4.1 Parent-Offspring Regression
[Content to be developed:]
\[
h^2 = b_{offspring,parent}
\]
(For one parent; double the regression coefficient if using midparent)

5.4.2 Half-Sib Correlation
[Content to be developed:]
\[
h^2 = 4 \times t_{HS}
\]
Where t_HS is the intraclass correlation among half-sibs.

5.4.3 Full-Sib Correlation
[Content to be developed: Includes dominance, so overestimates h¬≤.]

5.4.4 REML from Mixed Models
[Content to be developed: Modern approach using restricted maximum likelihood. Mention briefly, details beyond scope.]

title: 5¬† Heritability and Repeatability
text:
5.5 R Demonstration: Calculating Heritability
[Content to be developed:]

# Calculate heritability from variance components
sigma2_A <- 12.5   # Additive genetic variance (e.g., kg¬≤ for milk yield)
sigma2_E <- 32.5   # Environmental variance
sigma2_P <- sigma2_A + sigma2_E   # Phenotypic variance

h2 <- sigma2_A / sigma2_P
cat("Heritability:", round(h2, 3))

# Parent-offspring regression example
# (Simulated data)
set.seed(123)
n_families <- 100
parent_BV <- rnorm(n_families, mean = 0, sd = sqrt(sigma2_A))
offspring_BV <- 0.5 * parent_BV + rnorm(n_families, mean = 0, sd = sqrt(0.5 * sigma2_A))
offspring_pheno <- offspring_BV + rnorm(n_families, mean = 0, sd = sqrt(sigma2_E))

# Regression
model <- lm(offspring_pheno ~ parent_BV)
h2_estimated <- coef(model)[2]
cat("Estimated h¬≤ from regression:", round(h2_estimated, 3))

title: 5¬† Heritability and Repeatability
text:
5.6 Repeatability (r)
[Content to be developed: For traits measured multiple times on the same animal.]

5.6.1 Definition
[Content to be developed:]
\[
r = \frac{\sigma^2_A + \sigma^2_{PE}}{\sigma^2_P}
\]
Where:

r = repeatability
œÉ¬≤_PE = permanent environmental variance
œÉ¬≤_P = phenotypic variance (including temporary environmental variance œÉ¬≤_TE)

5.6.2 Interpretation
[Content to be developed: r is the correlation between repeated records on the same animal. It sets an upper bound on heritability.]

5.6.3 Relationship to Heritability
[Content to be developed:]
\[
h^2 \leq r
\]
If r = h¬≤, there are no permanent environmental effects.

title: 5¬† Heritability and Repeatability
text:
5.7 Permanent Environmental Effects (PE)
[Content to be developed: Environmental factors that permanently affect an animal‚Äôs performance across all records.]

5.7.1 Definition
[Content to be developed: Non-genetic effects that persist across records.]

5.7.2 Examples
[Content to be developed:]

5.7.3 Importance
[Content to be developed: PE effects cause repeated records on the same animal to be correlated, but this correlation is not genetic.]

title: 5¬† Heritability and Repeatability
text:
5.9 R Demonstration: Repeatability
[Content to be developed:]

# Simulate repeated records with permanent environmental effects
set.seed(456)
n_animals <- 100
n_records <- 5  # records per animal

sigma2_A <- 10
sigma2_PE <- 15
sigma2_TE <- 25  # Temporary environmental variance
sigma2_P <- sigma2_A + sigma2_PE + sigma2_TE

# Simulate
BV <- rnorm(n_animals, mean = 0, sd = sqrt(sigma2_A))
PE <- rnorm(n_animals, mean = 0, sd = sqrt(sigma2_PE))

data <- expand.grid(animal = 1:n_animals, record = 1:n_records)
data$BV <- BV[data$animal]
data$PE <- PE[data$animal]
data$TE <- rnorm(nrow(data), mean = 0, sd = sqrt(sigma2_TE))
data$phenotype <- data$BV + data$PE + data$TE

# Calculate repeatability as correlation between records
library(lme4)
model <- lmer(phenotype ~ (1 | animal), data = data)
var_components <- as.data.frame(VarCorr(model))
r_estimated <- var_components$vcov[1] / (var_components$vcov[1] + var_components$vcov[2])
cat("Estimated repeatability:", round(r_estimated, 3))

text:
5.10 Summary
[Content to be developed.]

5.10.1 Key Points

Heritability (h¬≤) quantifies the proportion of phenotypic variance due to additive genetic effects
Higher h¬≤ ‚Üí faster response to selection
Heritability is population- and environment-specific
Repeatability (r) is the upper limit of heritability
Permanent environmental effects cause repeated records to be correlated beyond genetics

title: 6¬† The Breeder‚Äôs Equation and Selection Response
text:
Learning Objectives

crumbs: 6¬† The Breeder's Equation and Selection Response

title: 6¬† The Breeder‚Äôs Equation and Selection Response
text:
6.1 Introduction
[Content to be developed: The breeder‚Äôs equation predicts how much genetic progress we can achieve per unit time. Understanding the four factors and their trade-offs is fundamental to designing breeding programs.]
crumbs: 6¬† The Breeder's Equation and Selection Response

title: 6¬† The Breeder‚Äôs Equation and Selection Response
text:
6.2 The Breeder‚Äôs Equation
[Content to be developed: Present the equation.]

6.2.1 The Equation
\[
R = \frac{i \times r \times \sigma_A}{L}
\]
Where:


R = response to selection per year (or per generation if L = 1)

i = selection intensity (standardized selection differential)

r = accuracy of selection (correlation between EBV and TBV)

œÉ_A = additive genetic standard deviation

L = generation interval (years)

6.2.2 Interpreting the Equation
[Content to be developed: Each factor contributes multiplicatively to genetic gain. Improving any factor increases R.]
crumbs: 6¬† The Breeder's Equation and Selection Response

title: 6¬† The Breeder‚Äôs Equation and Selection Response
text:
6.3 Selection Intensity (i)
[Content to be developed: How hard we select.]

6.3.1 Definition
[Content to be developed: i is the standardized selection differential. It depends on the proportion of animals selected as parents.]

6.3.2 Relationship to Proportion Selected (p)
[Content to be developed:]
\[
i = \frac{S}{\sigma_P}
\]
Where S is the selection differential (mean of selected - population mean).
For a given p, i can be looked up in a table or calculated.

6.3.3 Examples of Selection Intensity
[Content to be developed:]


Proportion Selected (p)
Selection Intensity (i)



0.01 (1%)
2.67


0.05 (5%)
2.06


0.10 (10%)
1.76


0.20 (20%)
1.40


0.50 (50%)
0.80



6.3.4 Factors Limiting Intensity
[Content to be developed:]

Genetic diversity (can‚Äôt select too few parents)
Number of offspring needed
Sex-limited traits (can only select females or males)
Practical constraints (cost, facilities)

6.3.5 Species Differences
[Content to be developed:]


Poultry: High intensity possible (thousands of candidates, high reproduction)

Dairy: Moderate intensity in males (AI), lower in females

Beef/Swine: Moderate intensity

Horses: Low intensity (low reproduction rate)
crumbs: 6¬† The Breeder's Equation and Selection Response

title: 6¬† The Breeder‚Äôs Equation and Selection Response
text:
6.4 Accuracy of Selection (r)
[Content to be developed: How well we predict true breeding values.]

6.4.1 Definition
[Content to be developed: r is the correlation between estimated breeding value (EBV) and true breeding value (TBV).]
\[
r = \text{cor}(EBV, TBV)
\]
Range: 0 to 1. Higher r means better prediction.

6.4.2 Factors Affecting Accuracy
[Content to be developed:]


Heritability: Higher h¬≤ ‚Üí higher r

Amount of information:

Own performance
Pedigree (parents, ancestors)
Progeny performance
Sibs and other relatives
Genomic data



Quality of information (measurement error)

6.4.3 Accuracy by Information Source
[Content to be developed:]


Information Source
Typical Accuracy (r)



Parent average (no own record)
0.30-0.45


Own performance (h¬≤=0.30)
0.55


Own + progeny (n=20)
0.75-0.85


Genomic selection (young animal)
0.50-0.70



6.4.4 Progeny Testing vs.¬†Genomic Selection
[Content to be developed: Progeny testing increases accuracy but requires waiting for progeny. Genomic selection provides moderate accuracy at birth.]
crumbs: 6¬† The Breeder's Equation and Selection Response

title: 6¬† The Breeder‚Äôs Equation and Selection Response
text:
6.5 Genetic Standard Deviation (œÉ_A)
[Content to be developed: The amount of additive genetic variation in the population.]

6.5.1 Definition
[Content to be developed:]
\[
\sigma_A = \sqrt{\sigma^2_A} = \sqrt{h^2 \times \sigma^2_P}
\]

6.5.2 Factors Affecting œÉ_A
[Content to be developed:]

Amount of genetic variation (historical effective population size)
Selection gradually reduces œÉ_A (reduces variation)
Mutation adds variation (very slowly)
Migration/crossbreeding can increase œÉ_A

6.5.3 Why We Can‚Äôt Easily Change œÉ_A
[Content to be developed: Unlike i, r, and L, œÉ_A is largely determined by the population‚Äôs genetic variation. Breeders have limited control.]
crumbs: 6¬† The Breeder's Equation and Selection Response

title: 6¬† The Breeder‚Äôs Equation and Selection Response
text:
6.6 Generation Interval (L)
[Content to be developed: Average age of parents when offspring are born.]

6.6.1 Definition
[Content to be developed:]
\[
L = \frac{L_{sires} + L_{dams}}{2}
\]

6.6.2 Species Differences
[Content to be developed:]


Species
Typical L (years)



Poultry
1.0


Swine
1.5-2.0


Sheep
2.5-3.5


Dairy cattle
4.0-6.0


Beef cattle
4.0-7.0


Horses
8.0-12.0



6.6.3 Factors Affecting L
[Content to be developed:]

Age at sexual maturity
Age when sufficient information is available (progeny testing)
Reproductive rate
Economic and facility constraints
crumbs: 6¬† The Breeder's Equation and Selection Response

title: 6¬† The Breeder‚Äôs Equation and Selection Response
text:
6.7 Trade-offs Among the Four Factors
[Content to be developed: The four factors are not independent. Optimizing one may compromise another.]

6.7.1 Accuracy vs.¬†Generation Interval
[Content to be developed: The classic trade-off]


Progeny testing: High accuracy (r ‚âà 0.80-0.90) but long L (6-8 years in dairy)

Genomic selection: Moderate accuracy (r ‚âà 0.50-0.70) but short L (2-3 years in dairy)

Net effect: Genomic selection often yields higher annual genetic gain despite lower accuracy

6.7.2 Intensity vs.¬†Generation Interval
[Content to be developed: Selecting very few parents (high i) may require keeping animals longer to obtain enough offspring.]

6.7.3 Intensity vs.¬†Inbreeding
[Content to be developed: Very high intensity reduces effective population size and increases inbreeding.]
crumbs: 6¬† The Breeder's Equation and Selection Response

title: 6¬† The Breeder‚Äôs Equation and Selection Response
text:
6.8 Comparing Selection Strategies
[Content to be developed: Use the breeder‚Äôs equation to compare different approaches.]

6.8.1 Example 1: Dairy Bull Selection
[Content to be developed:]
Progeny testing:

i = 2.06 (5% selected)
r = 0.85 (progeny-tested)
œÉ_A = 450 kg (for milk yield)
L = 6 years
R = (2.06 √ó 0.85 √ó 450) / 6 = 131 kg/year

Genomic selection:

i = 2.06
r = 0.65 (genomic EBV)
œÉ_A = 450 kg
L = 2.5 years
R = (2.06 √ó 0.65 √ó 450) / 2.5 = 241 kg/year

Result: Genomic selection yields ~84% higher annual gain despite lower accuracy.

6.8.2 Example 2: Swine Growth Rate
[Content to be developed: Numerical example comparing mass selection vs.¬†progeny testing.]
crumbs: 6¬† The Breeder's Equation and Selection Response

title: 6¬† The Breeder‚Äôs Equation and Selection Response
text:
6.9 R Demonstration: Breeder‚Äôs Equation Calculations
[Content to be developed:]

# Function to calculate response to selection
calculate_response <- function(i, r, sigma_A, L) {
  R <- (i * r * sigma_A) / L
  return(R)
}

# Example: Dairy milk yield
# Progeny testing
R_progeny <- calculate_response(i = 2.06, r = 0.85, sigma_A = 450, L = 6)
cat("Progeny testing R =", round(R_progeny, 1), "kg/year\n")

# Genomic selection
R_genomic <- calculate_response(i = 2.06, r = 0.65, sigma_A = 450, L = 2.5)
cat("Genomic selection R =", round(R_genomic, 1), "kg/year\n")

# Improvement
improvement <- (R_genomic / R_progeny - 1) * 100
cat("Genomic selection improves annual gain by", round(improvement, 1), "%\n")

text:
6.11 Summary
[Content to be developed.]

6.11.1 Key Points

The breeder‚Äôs equation predicts response to selection: R = (i √ó r √ó œÉ_A) / L
Four factors: intensity, accuracy, genetic SD, generation interval

title: 7¬† Estimating Breeding Values
text:
Learning Objectives

title: 7¬† Estimating Breeding Values
text:
7.1 Introduction
[Content to be developed: True Breeding Value (TBV) is unknown, but we can estimate it (EBV) from available information. This chapter covers methods from simple to sophisticated.]

title: 7¬† Estimating Breeding Values
text:
7.2 The Challenge: TBV is Unknown
[Content to be developed: We want to rank animals by TBV, but we can only observe phenotypes. We must estimate TBV from phenotypes, pedigrees, and genomic data.]

title: 7¬† Estimating Breeding Values
text:
7.3 Simple Estimation Methods
[Content to be developed: Basic approaches to estimating breeding values.]

7.3.1 Method 1: Own Performance
[Content to be developed:]
\[
\hat{BV} = h^2 (P - \mu)
\]
Where P is the individual‚Äôs phenotype and Œº is the population mean.
Accuracy: \(r = \sqrt{h^2}\)
Example: If h¬≤ = 0.36 and a pig weighs 100 kg while the mean is 90 kg, then EBV = 0.36 √ó (100 - 90) = 3.6 kg.

7.3.2 Method 2: Pedigree Index (Midparent BV)
[Content to be developed:]
\[
\hat{BV}_{offspring} = \frac{1}{2} (EBV_{sire} + EBV_{dam})
\]
Accuracy: \(r = \sqrt{\frac{h^2}{2}}\) (assuming parent EBVs are true BVs)
Used for young animals without own records.

7.3.3 Method 3: Progeny Average
[Content to be developed:]
\[
\hat{BV}_{parent} = 2 \times (\bar{P}_{progeny} - \mu)
\]
(Multiplied by 2 because progeny get half their genes from each parent)
Accuracy: Increases with number of progeny. For n progeny: \(r = \sqrt{\frac{n h^2}{4 + (n-1) h^2}}\)

7.3.4 Limitations of Simple Methods
[Content to be developed:]

Don‚Äôt account for contemporary group effects (environmental differences)
Don‚Äôt properly weight information sources by their accuracy
Don‚Äôt use all relatives simultaneously (e.g., sibs, grandparents)

title: 7¬† Estimating Breeding Values
text:
7.4 Contemporary Groups
[Content to be developed: Animals must be compared within the same environment.]

7.4.1 Definition
[Content to be developed: A contemporary group is a set of animals raised in the same environment and time period.]

7.4.2 Examples
[Content to be developed:]


Dairy: Herd-year-season

Beef: Ranch-year-season, weaning group

Swine: Farm-batch, pen (for within-farm comparisons)

Poultry: House-batch, cage-row

7.4.3 Why Contemporary Groups Matter
[Content to be developed: Without adjustment for environmental differences, animals in better environments appear genetically superior (false positive selection).]

7.4.4 Adjusting for Contemporary Groups
[Content to be developed: Subtract contemporary group mean before estimating BV.]
\[
\hat{BV} = h^2 (P - \mu_{CG})
\]
Where Œº_CG is the contemporary group mean.

title: 7¬† Estimating Breeding Values
text:
7.5 Best Linear Unbiased Prediction (BLUP)
[Content to be developed: The modern standard for estimating breeding values.]

7.5.1 What is BLUP?
[Content to be developed:]


Best: Minimizes prediction error variance

Linear: Linear function of the data

Unbiased: Expected value equals true BV

Prediction: For random effects (breeding values, not fixed effects like contemporary groups)

7.5.2 Why BLUP?
[Content to be developed:]


Uses all information: Own records, parents, progeny, sibs, and more distant relatives

Accounts for fixed effects: Contemporary groups and other systematic environmental effects

Optimal weighting: Information sources weighted by their accuracy

Shrinkage: EBVs shrink toward the population mean when information is sparse

7.5.3 BLUP Concepts (High-Level)
[Content to be developed: No mixed model equations (MME) at this level. Focus on concepts.]

Animals with more information ‚Üí EBVs closer to TBV
Animals with less information ‚Üí EBVs closer to parent average or population mean
Relationships among animals are accounted for
BLUP simultaneously solves for contemporary group effects and breeding values

7.5.4 BLUP in Practice
[Content to be developed: Most commercial breeding programs use BLUP or its extensions (genomic BLUP, single-step GBLUP).]

title: 7¬† Estimating Breeding Values
text:
7.6 Understanding EBVs
[Content to be developed: How to interpret estimated breeding values.]

7.6.1 EBV as a Deviation from the Base
[Content to be developed: EBVs are expressed as deviations from a base population (often set to zero mean in a specific year).]

7.6.2 Comparing Animals
[Content to be developed: Use the difference between EBVs, not absolute values.]
Example: Bull A has EBV = +500 kg for milk, Bull B has EBV = +300 kg. Bull A is expected to produce daughters that give 200 kg more milk than Bull B‚Äôs daughters (on average).

7.6.3 EBVs Change Over Time
[Content to be developed: As new data arrive (own records, progeny, genomic info), EBVs are re-estimated. Animals can be re-ranked.]

7.6.4 EBVs for Young vs.¬†Old Animals
[Content to be developed:]


Young: Based on pedigree (parents) and possibly genomics ‚Üí lower accuracy

Old: Based on own records, progeny, pedigree ‚Üí higher accuracy

title: 7¬† Estimating Breeding Values
text:
7.7 Accuracy of EBVs (Reliability)
[Content to be developed: Measure of confidence in the EBV.]

7.7.1 Definition
[Content to be developed:]
\[
\text{Reliability} = r^2 = \text{cor}^2(EBV, TBV)
\]
Range: 0 to 1.

7.7.2 Interpreting Reliability
[Content to be developed:]


r¬≤ = 0.90: EBV is very close to TBV (highly confident)

r¬≤ = 0.50: EBV is moderately accurate (moderate confidence)

r¬≤ = 0.20: EBV is still close to parent average (low confidence)

7.7.3 Factors Affecting Reliability
[Content to be developed:]

Heritability
Number of own records
Number of progeny records
Genomic information
Number and relationship of relatives with records

7.7.4 Using Reliability in Selection Decisions
[Content to be developed: Animals with high EBV but low reliability have more uncertainty. Consider both EBV and reliability when making selection decisions.]

title: 7¬† Estimating Breeding Values
text:
7.8 R Demonstration: Simple BV Estimation
[Content to be developed:]

# Example: Estimate BV from own performance
h2 <- 0.30
phenotype <- 95  # kg
pop_mean <- 90   # kg

EBV_own <- h2 * (phenotype - pop_mean)
cat("EBV from own performance:", EBV_own, "kg\n")

accuracy_own <- sqrt(h2)
cat("Accuracy:", round(accuracy_own, 3), "\n")

# Example: Midparent BV
EBV_sire <- 8
EBV_dam <- 6
EBV_offspring <- (EBV_sire + EBV_dam) / 2
cat("EBV from pedigree (midparent):", EBV_offspring, "kg\n")

# Example: Progeny average
progeny_mean <- 92
n_progeny <- 20
EBV_parent <- 2 * (progeny_mean - pop_mean)
cat("EBV from progeny average:", EBV_parent, "kg\n")

# Accuracy from progeny
r_progeny <- sqrt((n_progeny * h2) / (4 + (n_progeny - 1) * h2))
cat("Accuracy from", n_progeny, "progeny:", round(r_progeny, 3), "\n")

text:
7.9 Examples Across Species
[Content to be developed: Real-world EBV systems.]

[Content to be developed: EBVs for milk, fat, protein, fertility, health, longevity. Combined into a single index (Net Merit).]

[Content to be developed: Expected Progeny Differences for birth weight, weaning weight, yearling weight, carcass traits.]

[Content to be developed: EBVs for average daily gain, backfat, feed efficiency, litter size.]

7.9.4 Poultry: EBVs in Breeding Lines
[Content to be developed: EBVs for body weight, feed efficiency, egg production, egg quality (layers).]

title: 7¬† Estimating Breeding Values
text:
7.10 Summary
[Content to be developed.]

7.10.1 Key Points

True Breeding Value (TBV) is unknown but can be estimated (EBV)
Simple methods: own performance, pedigree index, progeny average
Contemporary groups must be accounted for to avoid environmental confounding
BLUP is the modern standard: uses all information, accounts for fixed effects, optimal weighting

Accuracy (reliability) measures confidence in EBV
EBVs can change over time as new data arrive
